I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
India for the Meghalaya Power Distribution Sector Improvement Project. The report also describes 
the proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
(JFPR) for the Meghalaya Power Distribution Sector Improvement Project, and if the Board 
approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve 
the administration of the grant. 
 
2.  The proposed project will strengthen and modernize the power distribution network, 
reduce technical and commercial losses, and improve the power quality of the distribution network 
in Meghalaya State. The project will enhance the institutional capacity of Meghalaya Power 
Distribution Corporation Limited (MePDCL) by (i) supporting the preparation of a distribution 
sector road map and financial road map to improve MePDCL’s planning capability, and financial 
performance and sustainability; (ii) introducing innovative components in project design; and (iii) 
building MePDCL’s capacity to monitor project implementation, including the environmental and 
social impacts of projects. The project will also support pilot testing of gender and socially inclusive 
renewable mini grid energy systems, which have the potential for future replication. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.   The state economy. Meghalaya is a state in northeastern India with a population of about 
3 million that shares its border on the north and east with the state of Assam, and on the south 
and west with Bangladesh. Meghalaya has the highest rainfall in India, recording an annual 
average of 12,000 millimeters. About 70% of the state is covered with forest. Meghalaya has 
some of the densest tropical rainforests in the country, and therefore constitutes one of the most 
important ecotourism destinations in India. Meghalaya’s economy is predominantly agrarian and 
has a significant commercial forestry-based industry. The state has abundant natural resources, 
including mineral deposits (such as coal, limestone, granite, and clay), and offers significant 
opportunities for investment. In fiscal year (FY) 2019, the primary sector (agriculture, forestry, 
mining, and quarrying) contributed 25.92% of gross state domestic product; the secondary sector 
(hydropower, agro-based and food processing, chemicals, and allied industries) contributed 
16.83%; and the tertiary sector, which is the fastest-growing sector, driven by trade, hotels, real 
estate,  finance,  insurance,  transport,  communication,  and  other  services,  contributed  the 
remaining 57.25%.1 Despite its rich resource endowments and tourism potential, industry in the 
state continues to lag behind other states because of its poor infrastructure facilities. With an 
average annual per capita income of ₹90,213, Meghalaya is one of the poorest states in the country 
and in the northeastern region.2 Meghalaya is also one of the few states in India that, despite having 
surplus availability, have low per capita electricity consumption of 832 kilowatt-hours (kWh) against 
the national average of 1,122 kWh in 2017.3 
 
4.  Power sector overview. Under the Meghalaya Power Sector Reforms Transfer Scheme 
2010, the state government unbundled the Meghalaya State Electricity Board into four separate 
companies along with their physical assets, properties, liabilities, obligations, and staff. The four 
successor  companies  are (i)  Meghalaya  Energy  Corporation  Limited (MeECL), the  holding

2  Statistics Times. 2019. Indian States by GDP per Capita. According to 2017–2018 data, only five states—Assam, 
Bihar, Jharkhand, Manipur, and Uttar Pradesh—have lower per capita incomes than Meghalaya. 
3  EnergySector.in. State-wise per Capita Consumption of Electricity in India.

company;  (ii)  Meghalaya  Power  Generation  Corporation  Limited,  the  generation  utility;  (iii) 
Meghalaya Power Transmission Corporation Limited, the transmission utility; and (iv) Meghalaya 
Power Distribution Corporation Limited (MePDCL), the distribution utility. Although the companies 
were officially unbundled, the lack of independent finance and administrative functions, together 
with  poor  financial  management  and  planning  capacity  of  subsidiaries,  hinders  them  from 
progressing towards financial sustainability. 
 
5.  Meghalaya had a total installed generating capacity of 613 megawatts (MW) in June 2018, 
of which 426 MW was generated from hydropower (355 MW4 owned by the state utility and 71 
MW from the central allocation), and the remaining 187 MW was from thermal-based generation 
capacity from the central government allocation to Meghalaya State.5 Meghalaya draws upon this 
central allocation to meet winter season deficits due to low generation from its hydropower plants. 
Peak demand in FY2017 reached 399 MW and is expected to reach 470 MW in FY2021. 
Additional generation capacity is required to achieve Meghalaya’s 24X7 Power for All initiative, 
which aims to bring an uninterrupted supply to each consumer in the state, even under the normal 
load-growth scenario.6 Meghalaya has surplus generation capacity during summer because of high 
hydropower availability and low demand, but it experiences a capacity deficit in winter because of 
high demand and low hydropower availability. 
 
6.  Power distribution issues. Although Meghalaya achieved 100% electrification for rural 
and urban households (635,802 consumers) in February 2019, the voltage at consumer premises 
drops below the allowable limit of 6% of the rated voltage during peak load periods. Further, power 
interruptions of more than 6 hours per day are common in remote rural networks. The average 
aggregate technical and commercial (AT&C) losses of the distribution network in 2017 were 
32.65%.7 AT&C losses attributable to three of the six circles of the Meghalaya distribution network 
(Central, East Garo Hills, and West Garo Hills) are estimated to be more than 50%. Further, the 
existing distribution network is overloaded. Most of the 33/11 kilovolt (kV) substations in rural 
areas have outdated technology and lack control rooms, making it difficult to operate the system, 
particularly during heavy rains and mist that are prevalent year-round in many parts of the state. 
MePDCL’s billing efficiency is only 67.35% as about 75% of the consumer meters installed by 
MePDCL are outdated, resulting in high commercial losses. High AT&C losses, aged distribution 
assets, and subsidized tariffs for the poor and agricultural consumers are the major reasons for 
the below-cost revenue recovery that has led to the poor financial state of the distribution utility. 
The huge capital requirements to develop the aged infrastructure, and the subsidized tariff in rural 
areas make rural electrification less attractive to the private sector. The proposed project will 
improve the reliability of distribution network, reduce AT&C losses, and improve financial viability 
and sustainability of MePDCL which may enable private sector participation and competition in 
the state’s retail distribution business in the future. 
 
7.  Government programs for the distribution sector. 24X7 Power for All Meghalaya was 
a joint initiative of the Government of India and the state government of Meghalaya to provide an 
uninterrupted,  quality,  reliable,  and  affordable  power  supply  to  all  domestic,  commercial, 
agricultural, and industrial consumers (footnote 6). MePDCL also signed an agreement with the 
Ministry of Power and the state government of Meghalaya under the Ujwal DISCOM Assurance

FY2020. This was to be achieved through various central government supported schemes, such 
as (i) the Integrated Power Development Scheme;9 (ii) Deen Dayal Upadhyaya Gram Jyoti 
Yojna;10 and (iii) Pradhan Mantri Sahaj Bijli Har Ghar Yojana (Saubhagya).11 Although Meghalaya 
achieved 100% electrification through the Saubhagya scheme, the state was not able to achieve 
the envisaged loss reduction target of 15% and the AT&C losses were at 34.8% in FY 2019. The 
implementation of identified measures for AT&C loss reduction are progressing slowly because 
of lack of sufficient funds. The project will help MePDCL implement some of these measures, 
such as metering, network strengthening, and billing efficiency improvement to reduce the AT&C 
losses.  
 
8.  Impact  of  coronavirus  disease.  The  global  pandemic  resulting  from  the  novel 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) has significantly impacted the country’s economy. The energy 
sector has not been spared, with the finances of state utilities detrimentally affected by reduced 
demand from remunerative industrial and commercial consumers. The real toll of the pandemic, 
however, is much higher, with livelihoods affected by the shutdown of tourism in the state. The 
electricity distribution works proposed in the project are essential activities to improve access to 
electricity in rural areas. These will also create construction-related jobs for the local community, 
including returning migrant workers who lost jobs, which will remain valid in a post COVID-19 
recovery phase. 
 
9.  Alignment with ADB and country priorities. The project is well aligned with the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030 operational priorities of (i) promoting rural development 
and food security, and addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities by improving access 
to electricity and creating economic opportunities in rural areas; (ii) accelerating progress in gender 
equality by creating gender and socially inclusive income-generating activities using renewable mini 
grids;  (iii)  tackling  climate  change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing 
environmental  sustainability  by  reducing  AT&C  losses  and  ensuring  efficient  distribution  of 
indigenous renewable hydropower; and (iv) strengthening institutional capacity by providing support 
in improving planning capability and financial performance.12 The proposed investment is also 
aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy for India, 2018–2022 for inclusive infrastructure in 
hinterlands and low-income states, and support for economic growth in the less-developed regions 
of the country.13 The project will support India’s Nationally Determined Contribution goals14 of 
emission reduction by lowering distribution losses, and United Nations Sustainable Development

Goals that focus on addressing poverty; empowering women; tackling climate change; and building 
resilient, reliable, sustainable and inclusive infrastructure.  
 
B.  Project Description 
 
10.  The project is aligned with the following impact: 24x7 power for all households, industries, 
commercial businesses, public needs, and other electricity consuming entities achieved (footnote 
6). The project will have the following outcome: efficiency, reliability, and quality of power supply 
to consumers at distribution level in Meghalaya improved.15 
 
11.  Output 1: Distribution network in Central, East Garo Hills, and West Garo Hills 
strengthened and modernized. To improve the reliability of power supply to rural electricity 
consumers and reduce technical losses, the project will (i) construct 23 new 33/11 kV substations, 
and renovation and modernization of 45 33/11 kV substations, including control room equipment 
and protection systems; (ii) install 136 auto-reclosers and 597 fault passage indicators at 11 kV 
and 33 kV lines; (iii) install and upgrade 2,214 kilometers (km) of 33 kV and 11 kV distribution lines; 
and (iv) renovate the rural distribution network to support mini grid in generation in three selected 
villages. 
 
12.  Output 2: System for meter reading, billing, and collection improved. To reduce 
commercial losses, the project will replace existing outdated electromechanical meters with smart 
meters targeting about 180,000 households (about 29% of consumers), and a new meter-testing 
laboratory will be installed and commissioned. The project will also implement a smart metering 
scheme with online meter reading, billing, and collection with automatic disconnection and 
reconnection of services for up to 75,000 consumers. The project will also be used to evaluate 
the technical and commercial feasibility for MePDCL in extending smart metering across the state 
in the future. 
 
13.  Output 3: Capacity of executing agency to plan and implement distribution sector 
projects strengthened. This will include support for (i) preparation of a distribution sector road 
map that will outline immediate, medium-term, and long-term investments, strategies, and policies 
to systematically develop the distribution sector to meet future system demands and service 
standards; (ii) preparation of a financial road map to support MePDCL in achieving financial 
sustainability  through  financial  improvement  action  plans  in  meeting  UDAY  Financial 
Restructuring Plan (FRP) targets, separating the financial and human resources functions of 
MePDCL from MeECL, and strengthening their internal audit systems; and (iii) implementation 
support to effectively monitor the project and ensure its technical, procurement, and safeguard 
compliances as required. The road maps and implementation support aim to develop MePDCL’s 
technical and financial capacity to systematically plan, design, and manage the distribution 
networks. 
 
14.  Output 4: Efficient and productive use of gender- and socially-inclusive mini grid 
energy systems pilot-tested and promoted. Renewable energy mini grids will be pilot-tested in 
the three villages (Lower Jambal, Dilma Ading, and Kosigre), and in three selected schools in the 
villages.16 The mini grids will improve power quality and support income generation, especially for 
women  and  other  socially  disadvantaged  groups,  using  indigenous  energy  resources.  The 
villagers will be engaged in income-generating activities and provided with relevant skills training, 
start-up capital, and support for market linkage. The project will conduct awareness-raising

sessions for villagers and students on mini grids and their productive use. The activities under 
output 4 will be supported by JFPR grant.   
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
15.  This project will be ADB’s first energy sector intervention in Meghalaya. ADB has rich 
financing experience in India through previous projects in other states, including in the northeastern 
state of Assam. ADB will be able to share the lessons and experiences gained from distribution 
improvement and strengthening projects in Madhya Pradesh and Sri Lanka, and rural electrification 
projects in Bangladesh and Nepal, and translate these experiences into robust project design and 
implementation.  ADB  will  help  MePDCL  establish  a  dedicated  project  management  unit  for 
implementing the project. In addition, ADB has assisted MePDCL in improving its procurement and 
safeguards monitoring capacity to meet the requirements of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009) and the procurement policy for ADB-financed investments. It is expected that MePDCL will 
mainstream the good practices embedded in ADB policies.  
 
16.  A comprehensive smart meter component incorporating online meter reading and billing 
with meter fault detection and monitoring feature will be implemented with the potential to expand 
coverage  across  the  entire  state  in  the  future.  ADB’s  experience  in  developing  mini  grid 
interventions17 using local energy resources to support gender- and socially-inclusive income-
generating activities in the underdeveloped and poor remote villages will also be explored. ADB has 
also assisted MePDCL in carrying out (i) surveys, (ii) geographic information system mapping of 
distribution networks, and (iii) network simulation in selected areas to ensure the design of the 
proposed project is optimal. Several distribution components with technology improvements18 will 
be introduced under the project to modernize their distribution system, adapt to extreme weather, 
and improve the robustness of the system. These project components will also reduce the power 
outages, and the operation and maintenance cost of the distribution system. 
 
D.  Summary Cost Estimates and Financing Plan 
 
17.  The project is estimated to cost $168.0 million (Table 1). The project team reviewed the 
impact of COVID-19 on the project and concludes that no significant impact is expected on 
implementation timeline and costs. The labor required for construction of distribution projects is 
locally available, and no restriction is imposed on supply of materials for essential services such 
as electricity distribution works.

18.  The government has requested a regular loan of $132.8 million from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources and $2 million grant from JFPR to help finance the project. The loan will have a 
20–year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years;  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility;  a 
commitment charge of 0.15% per year and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft 
loan and project agreements. Based on the straight-line method, the average maturity is 12.75 
years and maturity-based premium is therefore nil. The JFPR will provide grant cofinancing

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
24.  ADB staff undertook technical due diligence to establish the need for the proposed 
distribution improvement investment requirements in the context of supporting achievement of the 
UDAY targets agreed between the state government of Meghalaya and the central government. 
The climate change impact on the project is assessed as medium as the project area experiences 
monsoons and heavy rain. Medium-level risks associated with climate change impacts affecting 
the project area include damage to distribution lines and substation facilities because of more 
frequent and more severe extreme events (floods, storms, and lightning). The detailed project 
design has incorporated elements to address these risks, including siting of facilities away from 
flood-prone areas, construction of retaining walls, and installation of lightning protection. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
25.  Economic viability. The economic analysis was carried out in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects.21 Without the project, the aged and low-
efficiency distribution network would aggravate the current high losses and lead to poor-quality 
service in remote hilly areas. The project’s interventions would reduce distribution line losses, 
expand network capacity, and improve access to electricity in rural areas of Meghalaya. The 
economic analysis indicates an economic internal rate of return of 19.6% in constant 2019 prices. 
Given a hurdle rate of 9%, the project is deemed economically viable based on risk and sensitivity 
analyses.22 
 
26.  Financial viability. A financial cost–benefit analysis was conducted in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Financial Management and Analysis of Projects.23 With the project, 
commercial  losses  would  be  reduced  by  preventing  theft,  illegal  connections,  and  meter 
tampering; and by replacing defective meters. The project will also result in a significant reduction 
in technical losses, allowing MePDCL to buy less power to meet the same level of demand. The

9 
results, confirmed through sensitivity analysis, indicate a financial internal rate of return of 11.0%, 
which is above the weighted average cost of capital of 8.2%; therefore, the project is deemed 
financially viable. 
 
27.  The retail supply tariff will be priced based on the principles set by the jurisdictional 
regulator, the Meghalaya State Electricity Regulatory Commission, which allows full cost recovery 
through a tariff.24 The project would generate significant operating cash flows to MePDCL by 
AT&C losses reduction and achieving loss reduction target set by regulator for tariff revision. The 
financial internal rate of return for the proposed distribution investment was calculated in real 
terms on an after-tax basis using 2019 constant prices. 
 
C.  Sustainability 
 
28.  MePDCL faces critical financial and operational sustainability challenges. In FY2016–
FY2019, it recorded negative profits while its borrowings doubled, mainly because of high AT&C 
losses and insufficient tariffs. Meghalaya has a weak industrial base and a large share of domestic 
consumers living below the poverty line. Moreover, industry consumers that pay high tariffs have 
been  decreasing.  Furthermore,  Meghalaya’s  geographical  disadvantages  for  grid  electricity 
penetration lead to high losses. MePDCL’s weak financial position should therefore be understood 
in the context of these inherent limitations. 
 
29.  To  achieve  financial  turnaround,  the  government  and  MePDCL  have  taken  various 
actions,  which  include  implementing  a  financial  restructuring  plan  (FRP)  and  improving 
operational efficiency under the UDAY scheme (footnote 8). Under the UDAY FRP, MePDCL 
should meet the efficiency improvement target. This includes reducing AT&C losses to 15% by 
FY2020, which MePDCL has yet to achieve because of insufficient investment in the distribution 
system.25 Reducing AT&C losses and sustainably improving billing efficiency are the fundamental 
and immediate actions needed for MePDCL to achieve financial sustainability as per UDAY FRP. 
Hence, for the financial sustainability of Meghalaya’s power sector, immediate implementation of 
the project is needed. 
 
D.  Governance 
 
30.  As part of the power sector reforms in the state, the former Meghalaya State Electricity 
Board was unbundled in March 2010 into four companies: MeECL and its three subsidiaries (para 
4). The financial management of MeECL and its three subsidiaries is plagued by the lack of 
administrative  and  financial  autonomy  of  the  subsidiaries  to  manage  their  revenues  and 
expenditures. The assessed pre-mitigation financial management risk of MePDCL is substantial 
mainly because of the absence of a separate and independent finance and administrative 
function, significant delay in finalizing accounts, lack of an effective budgetary planning and 
control system, incomplete fixed asset management, and a weak internal audit system. 
 
31.  To  address  these  issues,  MeECL  and  MePDCL  have  agreed  on  comprehensive 
governance measures, including ADB’s support to enhance corporate governance and financial 
management.26 The financial road map to be prepared under this project will outline measures to

improve MePDCL’s capacity, including separation of the finance and administrative functions of 
MePDCL  from  MeECL,  monitoring  the  implementation  of  the  enterprise  resource  planning 
system, improving business processes to enable timely compilation of audited accounts and tariff

32.  Integrity due diligence was conducted.27 No significant integrity risks were identified. ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the 
government, MeECL, and MePDCL. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM (footnote 19).  
 
33.  The procurement capacity assessment of MePDCL was conducted as part of due diligence. 
Strategic procurement planning was conducted to maximize the value for money, and the following 
project procurement arrangements were chosen to lower transaction costs and realize economy 
and transparency: (i) strategic contract packaging by grouping dozens of sub packages of identical 
nature into one package for each circles; (ii) use of the borrower’s e-procurement system; and (iii) 
qualification criteria based on lowest evaluated cost. 
 
E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
34.  The project is located in areas where the majority of residents are poor (poverty target: 
general intervention). Access to a reliable electricity supply will help poor, vulnerable consumers, 
especially  women,  including  those  who  lack  or  have  limited  access  to  power.  Electricity 
consumers in the state’s rural areas and the urban area will be the primary beneficiaries. The 
project will contribute to improving the reliability of power supply for existing consumers, and will 
help provide an uninterrupted electricity supply for social infrastructure. 
 
35.  The project is categorized effective gender mainstreaming and a gender action plan has 
been  prepared.  The  JFPR  intervention  is  being  developed  with  an  objective  to  establish 
successful pilot for augmenting community-led income generation activities using renewable 
energy.  The  project  also  incorporates  gender  indicators  and  targets  to  promote  women’s 
participation in rural parts of Meghalaya and supporting capacity development of MeECL and 
MePDCL including gender equality and social inclusion aspects of the energy sector. The loan 
agreements will include standard assurances on core labor standards to be complied with by 
contractors. 
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
36.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.28 
 
37.  Environment  (category  B).  Given  the  nature,  scale,  and  location  of  the  project 
components, their potential direct, indirect, cumulative, and induced impacts are anticipated to be 
minor,  site-specific,  generally  reversible,  and  readily  mitigated.  An  initial  environmental 
examination (IEE) has been undertaken in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
and an environmental management plan (EMP) developed. Since the project involves existing 
facilities (45 substations), an environmental audit has been conducted for all substations and time-

Terrorism. Manila. 
28 ADB. Safeguard Categories.

11 
bound, budgeted corrective actions have been incorporated into the EMP.29 The IEE adequately 
identifies the project’s impacts and risks, and confirms it will not impact on legally protected areas 
or internationally or nationally important biodiversity areas or physical cultural resources. Most 
project impacts and risks are of temporary duration during construction.30 Pollution, health, and 
safety risks to workers and the community will remain during operation and maintenance works. 
Mitigation  and monitoring measures reflecting  international  good  practice  are  included  and 
budgeted for (about $0.5 million plus contractor costs) in the EMP along with performance 
indicators to be achieved, such that no residual significant impacts are anticipated. Given the 
limited  capacity  of  implementing  agencies  for  safeguards  implementation,  a  project 
implementation consultant will provide training and support the project management units in EMP 
implementation. Meaningful consultation,31 including with women, has been and will continue to 
be undertaken, as detailed in the IEE, which was disclosed locally and on the ADB website on 16 
April 2020. 
 
38.  Involuntary resettlement (category B). Potential impacts of distribution infrastructure 
and JFPR components on land acquisition and involuntary resettlement are not anticipated to be 
significant. The project will involve the construction of 23 new 33/11 kV substations, each requiring 
a small plot of land. About 5.75 hectares (ha) of land in total will be required for distribution 
substations and all the required land for the substations will be acquired through willing-buyer, 
willing-seller arrangements, and voluntary donation from communities. There should not be any 
coercion or threat of use of eminent domain in the process. Existing substations will be upgraded 
within their existing premises. Construction of 33 kV (771 km) and 11 kV (669 km) new distribution 
lines will pass mostly along the existing right-of-way of roads. The distribution lines are pole-
based, which do not require land acquisition.  
 
39.  For the JFPR components (output 4), a total of 3,031 square meters of land is required for 
the solar photovoltaic systems with agricultural processing units in three villages. Meaningful 
consultations have been undertaken, including with women. A combined draft resettlement and 
indigenous peoples plan (RIPP) has been prepared based on the assessment for the MePDCL 
and JFPR components, and in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and national 
regulations. MePDCL and MNREDA will need to secure the budget for RIPP implementation and 
provide the funds in a timely manner. 
 
40.  Indigenous peoples (category B). Meghalaya is predominantly a tribal state with about 
86% of total population belonging to a scheduled tribe. The project falls in the territory of East 
Garo Hills, West Garo Hills, and Khasi Hills, which belong to tribal areas according to the Sixth 
Schedule of the Constitution of India. Major tribes found in the project area are the Garo, Khasi, 
and Jaintia. The construction of substations, low-voltage lines, and the JFPR components will not 
affect the dignity, human rights, livelihood systems, or culture of the people, and all other impacts 
will be mitigated. There will be no involuntary land acquisition or resettlement of people from the 
scheduled  tribes.  Consent  letters  are  being  obtained  for  project  installations,  and  all  land 
acquisition will be completed before civil works contracts are awarded. There is no targeted 
intervention for indigenous peoples, and the project impacts are addressed by implementing 
resettlement measures, thus a combined draft RIPP has been prepared.

metadata.Subject: The proposed project will strengthen and modernize the power distribution network, reduce technical and commercial losses, and improve the power quality of the distribution network in Meghalaya State. The project will enhance the institutional capacity of Meghalaya Power Distribution Corporation Limited (MePDCL) by (i) supporting the preparation of a distribution sector road map and financial road map to improve MePDCL’s planning capability, and financial performance and sustainability; (ii) introducing innovative components in project design; and (iii) building MePDCL’s capacity to monitor project implementation, including the environmental and social impacts of projects. The project will also support pilot testing of gender and socially inclusive renewable mini grid energy systems, which have the potential for future replication.
